key_value.4907:
Unload
Unload the units from this Transport Ship.
key_value.4908:
Group
Group these units. When you click one unit, all units in the group are selected.
key_value.4909:
Ungroup
Disband this group so you can independently move each unit.
key_value.4910:
Select Formation
Choose the type of formation for these units. Units in formation take positions based on their combat role and stay together as they move around the map.
key_value.4913:
Chat
Send commands to allied computer players. In a multiplayer game, send typed messages or prerecorded taunts to other human players.
key_value.4914:
Diplomacy
Change your diplomatic stance (ally, neutral, enemy) toward other players. After you build a Market, also lets you send a tribute of resources to other players.
key_value.4915:
Menu
Save, restart, or quit this game, load a different game, or change your screen size, sound volume, and other options. (Hotkey: F10)
key_value.4916:
Statistics On
Turn on statistics that appear above the mini-map.
key_value.4917:
Statistics Off
Turn off the statistics that appear above the mini-map.
key_value.4918:
More Dock Items
Display the other ships and technologies.
key_value.4919:
Unload
Unload the units from this Siege Tower.
key_value.4922:
Stand Ground
Units ordered to stand ground do not move from their position to attack the enemy. They can attack from range if possible.
key_value.4923:
Attack Ground
Order the unit(s) to attack a location on the ground instead of a unit or building.
key_value.4924:
Heal
Order your Monk to heal a wounded unit to its full hit points.
key_value.4925:
Convert
Order your Monk to convert an enemy unit or building to your player color and control. The Monk must rest to restore his faith after a successful conversion.
key_value.4927:
Repair
Order your villager(s) to repair a building, ship, or siege weapon to its full hit points. The repair cost is deducted from your stockpile.
key_value.4928:
Turn Advanced Commands On
Display the buttons used to issue advanced commands, including the mini-map modes, score, signal allies, military unit tasks, combat stances).
key_value.4929:
Turn Advanced Commands Off
Hide the buttons used to issue advanced commands.
key_value.4932:
Statistics
Display the player/team scores. The manual explains how the score is calculated. In a multiplayer game, a red or yellow dot = player with slow connection speed. Turtle = slow computer speed. Players with their name crossed out were eliminated from the game.
key_value.4933:
Aggressive Stance
Aggressive units pursue enemies to the death or until the enemy leaves its sight.
key_value.4934:
Defensive Stance
Defensive units pursue enemies a short distance, then return to their post if the enemy leaves the area or is killed.
key_value.4935:
No Attack Stance
Units do not move and do not attack, even if they are attacked.
key_value.4936:
Guard
Order your unit(s) to guard another unit or building. Guard units attack enemy units that get close, then return to their post. Use the Aggressive Stance, Defensive Stance, and Stand Ground buttons to control how actively they pursue enemy units.
key_value.4937:
Follow
Order your unit(s) to follow another unit at long range to avoid detection. Use this to follow a villager or enemy unit back to its base or follow a Trade Cog or Trade Cart to find new Markets.
key_value.4938:
Patrol
Order your unit(s) to patrol an area.
key_value.4940:
Signal Allies
Send your allies a signal. They see a flashing X on the mini-map. Use this to alert your friends to resources, enemy bases, or where you need help.
key_value.4941:
Kill Your Unit
Kill unneeded low-power units if you reach the population limit. You cannot get the unit back if you kill it.
To destroy unused ships or buildings to allow for different ones, click the ship or building, then press the hotkey.
key_value.4944:
Set Gather Point
Choose where new units from this building gather after they are created. For instance, set a gather point on a forage bush to put newly created villagers to work automatically, or set a gather point on the Barracks to automatically garrison newly created infantry units.
key_value.4945:
Objectives
Display the objectives you must achieve to win this game. Some games also have hints.
key_value.4946:
Reseed Farm (‹cost›)
Click to add a Farm to the queue so that it is automatically replanted after it expires.
key_value.4949:
Remove Gather Point
Remove this building's gather point.
key_value.4950:
Ungarrison
Ungarrison all units from this ram.

To use the Zone, Age of Empires II: The Conquerors Expansion closes, then starts your Internet browser, which will go to the Zone web site.

key_value.20150:
Britons
Foot archer civilization

· Town Centers cost -50% wood in Castle Age
· Foot archers (except skirmishers) have +1 range Castle Age, +1 range
Imperial Age (for +2 total)
· Shepherds work 25% faster

Unique Unit: Longbowman (archer)

Unique Technology: Yeomen (+1 foot archer range; +2 tower attack)

Team Bonus: Archery Ranges work 20% faster
key_value.20151:
Franks
Cavalry civilization

· Castles cost -25%
· Knights +20% hit points
· Farm upgrades free (require Mill)

Unique Unit: Throwing Axeman (infantry)

Unique Technology: Bearded Axe (+1 Throwing Axemen range)

Team Bonus: Knights +2 line of sight
key_value.20152:
Goths
Infantry civilization

· Infantry cost -25% starting in Feudal Age
· Infantry +1 attack vs. buildings
· Villagers +5 attack vs. wild boar; hunters carry +15 meat
· +10 population in Imperial Age

Unique Unit: Huskarl (infantry)

Unique Techs: Anarchy (create Huskarls at Barracks); Perfusion (Barracks work 50% faster)
Team Bonus: Barracks work 20% faster
key_value.20153:
Teutons
Infantry civilization

· Monks healing range 2x
· Towers garrison 2x units
· Murder Holes free
· Farms cost -33%
· Town Center +2 attack, +5 line of sight

Unique Unit: Teutonic Knight (infantry)

Unique Tech: Crenellations (+3 range Castles; garrisoned infantry fire arrows)

Team Bonus: units resist conversion
key_value.20154:
Japanese
Infantry civilization

· Fishing Ships 2x hit points; +2P armor; work rate +5% Dark, +10% Feudal, +15% Castle, +20% Imperial Age
· Mill, Lumber/Mining Camps cost -50%
· Infantry attack 25% faster starting in Feudal Age

Unique Unit: Samurai (infantry)

Unique Technology: Kataparuto (Trebuchets fire, pack faster)

Team Bonus: galleys +50% line of sight
key_value.20155:
Chinese
Archer civilization

· Start with +3 villagers but -50 wood, -200 food
· Technologies cost -10% Feudal,
-15% Castle, -20% Imperial Age
· Town Centers support 10 population
· Demolition ships +50% hit points

Unique Unit: Chu Ko Nu (archer)

Unique Technology: Rocketry (+2P Chu Ko Nu attack, +4P scorpions)

Team Bonus: Farms +45 food
key_value.20156:

Defensive civilization

· Buildings +10% HPs Dark, +20% Feudal, +30% Castle, +40% Imperial Age

· Town Watch free

Unique Tech: Logistica (Cataphracts cause trample damage)

Team Bonus: Monks +50% heal speed
key_value.20157:

Unique Unit: War Elephant (cavalry)

Team Bonus: knights +2 attack vs. archers
key_value.20158:

researching gunpowder technologies

key_value.24564:
Restart
This button restarts the replay of the game from the beginning.
key_value.24565:
View Lock Toggle
When selected, follows what the player was watching when the game was recorded.
key_value.24566:
Fog of War Toggle
This button turns on or off the fog of war (gray shading).
key_value.24567:
Demo Loop Toggle
This button enables looping the recorded game.
key_value.24569:
Fast Playback
This button speeds up the playback.
key_value.24570:
Slow Playback
This button slows down the playback.
key_value.24571:

key_value.26089:
Build Trade Cog (‹cost›)
Used to trade with other players by sea. Carries goods from your Dock to another player's Dock and brings back gold. The farther the Dock, the higher your profit. To trade, click the Trade Cog, then right-click an allied or neutral Dock. Upgrades: generate more gold (Market); armor, cost (Dock); more resistant to Monks (Monastery).

Build Fishing Ship (‹cost›)
Gathers food from jumping fish and Fish Traps. Returns fish to the Dock automatically in the same way villagers return food to the Town Center. Upgrades: armor, cost, speed, efficiency (Dock); more resistant to Monks (Monastery).

Build Bombard Cannon (‹cost›)
Powerful mobile anti-building siege weapon. Attack bonus vs. buildings, ships. Can be used vs. units but excels vs. structures. Weak vs. close nonranged units. Upgrades: attack, range (University); more resistant to Monks (Monastery).

Slow, lumbering siege weapon used to reduce enemy towns to ruins. Attack bonus vs. buildings; resistant to archer attack. Infantry and foot archers can garrison inside for protection. key_value.28315:

Monks can convert enemy buildings (except Town Centers, Castles, Monasteries, Farms, Fish Traps, walls, Gates, and Wonders) and siege weapons. Monks can convert most enemy units from a distance, but they must stand adjacent to buildings, rams, and Trebuchets to convert them.

key_value.28408:
Research Spies/Treason (Cost: 200 per enemy villager for Spies/400 per use for Treason)
Spies (Random Map games) reveals all enemy units and buildings by showing you their line of sight. The total cost is 200 gold per each enemy villager.

Treason (Regicide games) reveals the position of all enemy Kings to your team for a few seconds. The Kings appear on the mini-map as a flashing X. Each time you choose Treason, 400 gold is immediately deducted from your stockpile.

key_value.30110: Arabia - Arid desert with strategic elevations and cliffs, but sparse vegetation and water.
key_value.30111: Arena - The walls around your forest clearing are your only protection from the carnage in the middle.
key_value.30112: Archipelago - A group of large islands. You might not be the only inhabitant on yours.
key_value.30113: Baltic - An ocean with peninsulas and sheltered bays.
key_value.30114: Black Forest - Islands of grass in a sea of trees. Follow the paths through the forest to find your allies and enemies.
key_value.30115: Coastal - Where the land meets the ocean, with plenty of water and a large landmass for battles by land or by sea.
key_value.30116: Continental - A large body of land surrounded by the sea; rivers may separate players and teams.
key_value.30117: Crater Lake - An island brimming with gold in the center of a caldera lake. Steep elevation and lack of trees make it hard to build there.
key_value.30118: Fortress - A walled city with gates and all the buildings you need to build up your forces quickly.
key_value.30119: Ghost Lake - The central lake is frozen over, creating a no-man's land.
key_value.30120: Gold Rush - A whole heap of gold and a few wolves in the middle of a desert.
key_value.30121: Highland - Far from the ocean and heavily forested but with plenty of rivers and open space for maneuvers.
key_value.30122: Islands - Each player starts alone on an island; uninhabited islands may be rich with resources so be prepared to rule the sea.
key_value.30123: Mediterranean - An inland sea surrounded by land; sounds deceptively peaceful.
key_value.30124: Migration - A tiny island that can't support you for long before you must move to the mainland, where the fighting is fierce.
key_value.30125: Mongolia - Cliffs abound on these parched and endless steppes.
key_value.30126: Nomad - Your villagers begin scattered without a Town Center or Scout Cavalry. Will you build a town immediately or struggle to find the perfect location to settle?
key_value.30127: Oasis - Nearly all of the wood is in the center of the map, so prepare to be chased around and around.
key_value.30128: Rivers - Players are isolated by narrow rivers; numerous shallows must be guarded at all cost.
key_value.30129: Salt Marsh - Swampy lowlands full of shallows and rivers that can prohibit expansionistic building.
key_value.30130: Scandinavia - In the northern wilderness the berry bushes have all frozen, but there are hungry animals to be hunted and plenty of gold to be found.
key_value.30131: Team Islands - One island shared by you and your allies, and another inhabited by your enemies. The islands are not connected by shallows, so beware of enemy Transport Ships.
key_value.30132: Yucatan - In the tropical rainforest food is abundant, but jaguars stalk beneath the canopy.
key_value.30133: Full Random - Chooses one of the following maps: Arabia, Archipelago, Baltic, Coastal, Continental, Ghost Lake, Highland, Islands, Mediterranean, Migration, Mongolia, Oasis, Rivers, Scandinavia, Team Islands, or Yucatan.
key_value.30134: Random Land - Chooses one of the following maps: Arabia, Ghost Lake, Highland, Mongolia, Oasis and Yucatan.
key_value.30135: Iberia - The Iberian Peninsula, including Spain and Portugal.
key_value.30136: Britain - Expect lots of naval combat in the North Sea and across the English Channel.
key_value.30137: Mideast - Where continents, cultures, and world religions collide.
key_value.30138: Texas - Relive the classic Mayan and Korean skirmish over the Lone Star state.
key_value.30139: Italy - Rome has fallen and the peninsula is up for grabs.
key_value.30140: Central America - The Aztecs and Mayans vie for domination of Central America with invaders from across the sea.
key_value.30141: France - Re-enact the Moslem invasion and the Hundred Years War.
key_value.30142: Norse Lands - Norway, Sweden, Finland, Denmark, and Holland.
key_value.30143: Sea of Japan (East Sea) - Japanese warships and Korean Turtle Ships do battle in this rocky sea.
key_value.30144: Byzantium - Rome never truly fell, it just changed continents.
key_value.30146: Acropolis - Battle on the barren slopes of your base as you defend your hill and conquer the enemy's.
key_value.30147: Blind Random - Chooses one of the following maps: Arabia, Archipelago, Baltic, Black Forest, Coastal, Continental, Crater Lake, Ghost Lake, Gold Rush, Highland, Islands, Mediterranean, Migration, Mongolia, Oasis, Rivers, Salt Marsh, Scandinavia, Team Islands, or Yucatan.
key_value.30148: Cenotes - An open land studded with sinkholes but only a few clusters of trees.
key_value.30149: City of Lakes - An endless maze of lakes and rivers winding through a sparsely forested desert.
key_value.30150: Golden Pit - A ravine filled with gold beckons but its depths loom treacherously as enemies lie in wait on the other side.
key_value.30151: Hideout - A palisade wall provides only false comfort over the palpable feeling of enemy lurking just around the corner.
key_value.30152: Hill Fort  - A fortified stronghold perched on a mountain top may be virtually impregnable but scarce resources and lack of space drive players to expand their empires into the lowlands around.
key_value.30153: Lombardia - A handful of cities on opposite ends of a wintry landscape must share, trade and coordinate in their efforts to defeat the enemy.
key_value.30154: Steppe - Dare you leave the safe shelter of the trees to hunt the graceful deer roaming the open ground?
key_value.30155: Valley - A dried up river stands between enemy towns but also poses an opportunity as animals gather there to gulp down the last drops.
key_value.30156: MegaRandom - Ever dreamed of an endlessly unpredictable map where anything is possible and nothing is guaranteed? Multiply it by ten and you have... MegaRandom
key_value.30157: Hamburger - The ultimate Easter Egg map. Located on either side of the tasty burger, will you eat through it, or sail around the bun and surprise the enemy?
key_value.30158: Budapest - Two towns and a plethora of wildlife offer unconventionally intense battles
key_value.30159: CtR Random - A compilation of gameplay-enhancing maps designed specifically for Capture the Relic mode! Dozens of wildly different layouts further challenge the aspects of the game mode, and guarantee an unpredictable, yet highly fulfilling experience.
key_value.30160: CtR Monsoon - One of the three most challenging Capture the Relic maps. There is only limited space to build on as most of the map is covered in endless marshes, which in the coldest seasons turn to ice. The relic stands in the centre, enclosed in a sacred grove of trees.
key_value.30161: CtR Pyramid Descent - One of the three most challenging Capture the Relic maps. Players appear huddled up around the relic atop a vast pyramid but their monasteries lie all the way on the bottom stair.
key_value.30162: CtR Spiral - One of the three most challenging Capture the Relic maps. The center of the map has been engulfed in a spiral of deep waters and the only way to reach the relic is to follow the current in long and treacherous circles.
key_value.30170: Random Map - Most common game; you choose the settings and victory conditions.
key_value.30171: Regicide - Your King must be the last to survive. If your King dies, you're out of the game.
key_value.30172: Death Match - All players start with huge stockpiles of wood, food, gold, and stone and then fight to the death.
key_value.30173: Scenario - Play a custom map that you or someone else created.
key_value.30174: King of the Hill - Control the Monument in the center of the map for the specified time to win. To control the Monument, kill all of the enemy units around it.
key_value.30175: Wonder Race - No combat; the first player to build a Wonder wins.
key_value.30176: Defend the Wonder - Player 1 starts with a Wonder surrounded by walls and must defend it from enemy players or teams to win. All players start in the Imperial Age with all technologies researched and huge stockpiles of resources.
key_value.30177: Turbo Random Map - Buildings create units faster, villagers gather faster, build faster, and carry more.
key_value.30178: Capture the Relic - Be the first player to capture the relic in the center of the map and return it to your monastery. Each player's monastery is indestructible and you cannot build additional monasteries.
key_value.30190: Standard - Win by being the first player or team to destroy all enemies in military conquest, control all Relics, or build a Wonder.
key_value.30191: Conquest - Win by destroying all enemies in military conquest.
key_value.30192: Time Limit - The player or team with the highest score when the time runs out wins.
key_value.30193: Score - The first player or team to achieve the required score wins.
key_value.30194: Last Man Standing - No allied victory. Team members must ultimately turn on each other until there is only one player left.
key_value.30201: Click to see the player names. In a multiplayer game, close some of the positions to limit a game to fewer than 8 players. Closing a position occupied by a player ejects that player from the game.
key_value.30202: Click to select a civilization. Each civilization has special abilities and can research different technologies. Click the Technology Tree button (bottom of screen) to learn more about each civilization. More than one player can select the same civilization.
key_value.30204: Click to change the scenario settings (such as the type and size of the map, game speed, and the game's victory condition).
key_value.30206: Type a message to other players.
key_value.30208: Select the number of computer players you want in your game. You can issue commands to allied computer players using the Chat window.
key_value.30209: Click to invite a friend to join this game.
key_value.30210: Click when you are ready to start the game. The game creator cannot start the game until all players are ready. The names of players who are ready are shown in green.
key_value.30211: Click to select your team number. Players on the same team automatically have their diplomatic stance set to Ally and Allied Victory set. A dash (-) indicates no team. A question mark (?) indicates random teams.
key_value.30212: Click to select your player's color and starting position on the map. In a multiplayer game, if two or more players select the same player number, they can play a cooperative game and share control of the same civilization.
key_value.30213: Click to start the game. You cannot click this button until you select the I'm Ready! check box.
key_value.30214: Click to display the technology trees for the different civilizations.
key_value.30250: Select the map size. The larger the map, the longer the game.
key_value.30251: Select the distribution of land and water on the map.
key_value.30252: Select the victory condition you must achieve to win the game.
key_value.30256: Select the maximum age that the game will progress to. Imperial Age is the standard setting. Post-Imperial Age is just the Imperial Age with all tech researched, so it's no different than Imperial as an ending age.
key_value.30257: Select the age in which the game starts. Dark Age is the standard setting. If you choose Castle Age, you start the game with all technology and unit upgrades from the Feudal Age, but you must still research the Imperial Age. Post-Imperial Age is the Imperial age with all of the tech trees already researched.
key_value.30258: Select the amount of wood, food, stone, and gold in each player's stockpile when the game starts.
key_value.30259: Select to have players begin the game in fixed (clockwise) positions based on their player number. Team members with consecutive player numbers are located adjacent to each other on the map. If not selected, players begin the game in random locations on the map.
key_value.30260: Select how much of the map is revealed when you start the game. Normal: You must explore to reveal the map and find your opponents. Explored: You can see the map but must explore to find your opponents. All Visible: You can see the map and your opponents when you start the game.
key_value.30263: Select if you want each civilization to lose its special abilities and be able to research all technologies in the game.
key_value.30264: Select to allow all players to use the cheat codes.
key_value.30266: Explains what you must do to win the game.
key_value.30267: Select the time limit for the game. The civilization with the highest score at the end of the required time period wins the game.
key_value.30268: Select the score for the game. The first civilization to achieve this score or military conquest wins the game.
key_value.30269: Select the skill level of the computer players.
key_value.30270: Select the pathfinding capability. The higher the setting, the more efficiently units find paths from one location to another. Higher values also require faster computers.
key_value.30271: Select the maximum number of units each player can create. The recommended value is 75. Higher values require faster computers.
key_value.30272: If this box is selected, the last saved multiplayer game will be restored.
key_value.30273: Select the type of game you want to play.
key_value.30274: Select the range of how close the game host must be to you.
key_value.30275: Select how fast units move and game time elapses. Changing the game speed affects all players.
key_value.30276: Select to prevent players from changing teams or tributing resources and chatting privately with nonallied players after the game starts. (Team games only)
key_value.30277: Select to prevent players from changing the game speed after the game starts.
key_value.30278: Select to record the game. To replay a recorded game, select it on the Saved Game screen to replay it automatically.
key_value.30279: Click to return game settings to their default values.
key_value.30280: Select the type of map to use. On a Standard map, the terrain is different every game. On a Real World map, the terrain is similar to the geography of a real location, but resources and starting locations are still random. On a Special map, terrains follow special patterns, but resources are still random.
key_value.30281: Select to only show games that are Ranked.
key_value.30282: Select to only show games with a specific game speed.
key_value.30301: Click to add a new player name.
key_value.30302: Click to remove a player name.
key_value.30311: Explains what you must do to win the game.
key_value.30320: Type a name for the game.
key_value.30350: Click to set your diplomatic stance toward this player to Ally. Your military units will not attack this civilization.
key_value.30351: Click to set your diplomatic stance toward this player to Neutral. Your military units will attack all buildings and military units (but not villagers) that enter their line of sight.
key_value.30352: Click to set your diplomatic stance toward this player to Enemy. Your military units (except Scout Cavalry) will attack all buildings, military units, and villagers that enter their line of sight.
key_value.30353: Click to tribute this player 100 wood. Each time you click the button, a transaction fee is also deducted from your stockpile. Researching Coinage and Banking (at the Market) reduces the fee. To tribute lots of 500, hold down the SHIFT key, and then click the button. To tribute everything in your stockpile, hold down the CTRL key, and then click the button.
key_value.30354: Click to tribute this player 100 food. Each time you click the button, a transaction fee is also deducted from your stockpile. Researching Coinage and Banking (at the Market) reduces the fee. To tribute lots of 500, hold down the SHIFT key, and then click the button. To tribute everything in your stockpile, hold down the CTRL key, and then click the button.
key_value.30355: Click to tribute this player 100 gold. Each time you click the button, a transaction fee is also deducted from your stockpile. Researching Coinage and Banking (at the Market) reduces the fee. To tribute lots of 500, hold down the SHIFT key, and then click the button. To tribute everything in your stockpile, hold down the CTRL key, and then click the button.
key_value.30356: Click to tribute this player 100 stone. Each time you click the button, a transaction fee is also deducted from your stockpile. To tribute everything in your stockpile, hold down the CTRL key, and then click the button.
key_value.30357: Click to clear all tributes before they are paid.
key_value.30358: If this box is selected, allied players win or lose as a team. Any allied player who achieves the victory condition wins the game for all allies. All players who want to pursue an allied victory must select Allied Victory.
key_value.30500: Click to create a randomly generated or custom map.

key_value.30502: Click to choose the starting age, starting stockpiles, civilization, starting technology, and computer personality for each player.

key_value.30504: Click to choose unique victory conditions for each player.
key_value.30505: Click to write scenario instructions, hints, a victory message, a loss message, and historical information.

key_value.30507: Click to enable the full tech tree or to disable technology for each player.

key_value.30509: Click to select one or more victory conditions that all players must achieve.

key_value.30528: Click to select the brush size.
key_value.30529: Click to select the brush size.

key_value.35429: 1. All Roads Lead to a Besieged City
key_value.35928:
Joan of Arc:
It is a war that has lasted for one hundred years, and the French have lost nearly every battle. Soon the English and their allies in Burgundy will conquer all of France. The heir to the French monarchy is too cowardly to ascend to the throne. The French army is wounded and tired and has given up all hope. But in the darkest hour, a young peasant girl declares that she intends to save France.
key_value.35958:
Saladin:
Outraged that the Holy Land is ruled by Saracens, knights from Europe have descended upon the Middle East in a series of Crusades. Now four European kingdoms have sprung up in the desert. The Saracen king, Saladin, rallies his troops in an attempt to drive back the invaders. In response to European Crusades, the Saracens have organized a Jihad. In response to European vileness, the once-cultured Saracens have become treacherous. But will it be enough to save their homeland?
key_value.35988:
Genghis Khan:
The nomadic tribes of the Asian steppes spent centuries entangled in their own petty feuds until united under Genghis Khan. Within years, a highly disciplined army pours out of Mongolia to embark on a campaign of world conquest. But how can a tribe of horse archers possibly overcome the military might of Persia and Eastern Europe, let alone the technologically advanced empires in China?
key_value.36018:
Barbarossa:
Can the will of one man forge an empire? Frederick Barbarossa attempts to force the squabbling German fiefdoms into his Holy Roman Empire, which he then must defend from the machinations of the Italian city states and the pope in Rome. And should he accomplish all of those feats, there is always the Third Crusade to wage.
key_value.36138:
William Wallace (Learning Campaign):
The warriors of Scotland attempt to hold off an invasion of the better-equipped English armies. Take command of the highlanders, and learn the basic concepts of Age of Empires II: HD Edition, such as how to build an economy, how to train your soldiers and, most importantly, how to fight and defeat your enemy. If you are new to real-time strategy games, you will learn all you need to know. If you have played the original Age of Empires, then you can skip ahead to new features, such as garrisoning and formations.
key_value.36167: Experienced Age of Empires players may start with Scenario 6 - Forge an Alliance
key_value.36228:
Attila the Hun:
Barbarian hordes feast on the dying Roman empire. The most dangerous of these invaders are the Huns and their ferocious king, Attila. After pouring out of the Caspian steppes, looting and burning all the while, the Huns become so powerful that the Roman Empire is forced to pay a tribute to Attila. But the king of the Huns is still not satisfied, and he mobilizes his horsemen to invade Gaul and eventually Rome itself! Can nothing stop the brutal Attila?
key_value.36258:
El Cid:
Spain is divided between Christian kingdoms to the north and Moorish kingdoms to the south. In the barren borderlands of Castille, Rodrigo Díaz, called El Cid, gains notoriety as a brilliant general and heroic crusader. The Cid is so popular among soldiers and peasants alike that the distrustful King of Castille sends him into exile. The Cid must join forces with his former enemies, the Moors, and fight against his beloved Castille. But an even greater threat waits across the sea in Africa, where fanatical Berber horsemen are eager to seize what the Moors could not.
key_value.36288:
Montezuma:
Centuries of conquest have allowed the Aztecs to become the mightiest empire in Central America. But when strangers appear on the shores of the Caribbean Sea, Montezuma, emperor of the Aztecs, is unsure whether they are conquerors…or gods. Can a vast empire of warriors using obsidian spears and cotton armor hold off mounted invaders armed with metal armor and gunpowder? Will the Aztec island-city of Tenochtitlan continue to conquer the Americas, or will it crumble beneath these foreign conquerors?
key_value.36318:
The Conquerors:
Certain names ring down through history as men and women who shaped the world. Some were forces of chaos, destructive and rapacious. Some were men of honor who fought for the right. Some defended their homelands from invaders, while others used their military might to violently acquire the lands of others. Battles such as Agincourt, Manzikert, and Hastings are remembered as turning points in world history, and names such as Henry V, Yi Sun-shin, and Erik the Red are etched forever as great conquerors. Now relive their tragedies and triumphs.
key_value.36428:
Alaric:
The trauma of the Hun invasion in the 4th century has shaped Alaric, the fearsome warrior king of the Goths. Fleeing his ravaged homeland as a child, Alaric spent the rest of his life searching for a new place to call home. Can the beloved king secure a new homeland for his people in the territory of the collapsing Roman Empire?
key_value.36458:
Dracula:
History forged an incredible legend around the man who ruled Wallachia in the mid-15th century. Holding his ground against the vast armies of the expanding Ottoman Empire, his cruel tactics made him the most feared man in all of Eastern Europe. Shall his thirst for blood and the loyalty of his soldiers be enough to hold the Turks back for good?
key_value.36488:
Bari:
400 years after the collapse of the Roman empire, Italy is still up for grabs. In the deep south, Byzantines, Goths, Normans and Muslims all vie for control of the port city of Bari. Relive the tale of the city from the point of view of a Byzantine family, rising from the common soldiery to the nobility. But beware, for not only Bari is at stake, but also control of Southern Italy.
key_value.36518:
Sforza:
After witnessing the death of his father, the young captain did not hesitate to take over command of his father's Condottieri. Always hungry for glory and wealth, Sforza wanders around 15th century Italy, offering his services to the highest bidder. Will he pick the right battles or make the wrong enemy? Take the fate of the young mercenary captain in your hands.
key_value.36548:
El Dorado:
Join Francisco Orellana and Gonzalo Pizarro on their quest to find El Dorado, the legendary Lost City of Gold, thought to be hidden somewhere in the vast Amazon rain forest. Will their quest along the Amazon river lead to lifelong prosperity or will they drown in their sorrow?
key_value.36578:
Prithviraj:
As the 12th century comes to a close, India is divided between the ruling Rajput clans. One of them, the Chauhans, have just been blessed with a new king. His name is Prithviraj and his determination to unite the rival states is unprecedented. But what happens when he falls in love with the daughter of his enemy? And does he have the strength to stop a full-scale Muslim invasion from the west?
key_value.36608:
Battles of the Forgotten:
Time has faded the names of many of the greatest leaders ever known. During their age they were famed for their fierceness on the battlefield, their just rule and their quest for power. Witness the path to glory of Richard the Lionheart, Minamoto no Yoritomo, Sultan Osman Ghazi, Khosrau and many more.

key_value.41006:
Disband Formation
Disband this formation so you can independently move each unit.
key_value.41014:
Ungarrison (All Units)
Ungarrison all units from this building.
key_value.41015:
Send Villagers Back to Work
Ungarrison all villagers from this building and send them back to work.
key_value.41017:
Wheel Right
Turn the formation clockwise 1/8 of a circle. The units maintain relative positions.
key_value.41018:
Wheel Left
Turn the formation counterclockwise 1/8 of a circle. The units maintain relative positions.
key_value.41019:
Horde
Form the units into a group with no specific organization. The group will try to stay together as it moves around the map.
key_value.41020:
Box Formation
Form the units into a protective box, with weaker units in the center, offering them maximum protection from attack in any direction.
key_value.41021:
Line Formation
Form the units into a line wider than it is deep. Military units are positioned according to their specialty.
key_value.41022:
Staggered Formation
Form the units into a staggered line formation, in which units are farther apart to mitigate the type of damage caused by siege weapons when units are too close together.
key_value.41023:
Flank Formation
Form the units into two subgroups, which then try to surround the enemy when attacking.
key_value.41050:
Normal Mini-map
Display all units and buildings on the mini-map. Click the Statistics button in Normal mode to see the scores of all players.
key_value.41051:
Combat Mini-map
Display only combat units on the mini-map. Click the Statistics button in Combat mode to see how many combat units you have listed by class (cavalry, siege units, warships, and so forth).
key_value.41053:
Economic Mini-map
Display only idle villagers, trade buildings, and trade units on the mini-map. You only see other players' trade buildings. Click the Statistics button in Economic mode to see how many villagers you have idle, by task, and the commodity exchange rates if you have a Market.
key_value.41055:
Pack
Dismantle this Trebuchet so you can move it. You must unpack it when it reaches its destination. Packed Trebuchets are vulnerable to attack.
key_value.41056:
Unpack
Assemble this Trebuchet into a stationary unit. Trebuchets are vulnerable while unpacking.
key_value.41061:
Buildings
Display the economic and infrastructure buildings you can build.
key_value.41062:
Military Buildings
Display the military buildings you can build.
key_value.41068:
Garrison
Garrison the selected unit inside of a building for protection and healing.
key_value.41072:
Click to sell 100 wood for %d gold
Each time you click, 100 wood is deducted from your stockpile and you receive the amount of gold shown on the button. The price may change with each click. To sell lots of 500, hold down the SHIFT key, and then click the button.
key_value.41073:

Each time you click, 100 food is deducted from your stockpile and you receive the amount of gold shown on the button. The price may change with each click.To sell lots of 500, hold down the SHIFT key, and then click the button.
key_value.41074:

Each time you click, 100 stone is deducted from your stockpile and you receive the amount of gold shown on the button. The price may change with each click. To sell lots of 500, hold down the SHIFT key, and then click the button.
key_value.41076:

Each time you click, 100 wood is added to your stockpile and you pay the price in gold shown on the button. The price may change with each click. To buy lots of 500, hold down the SHIFT key, and then click the button.
key_value.41077:

Each time you click, 100 stone is added to your stockpile and you pay the price in gold shown on the button. The price may change with each click. To buy lots of 500, hold down the SHIFT key, and then click the button.

Technology Tree
Click to display the technology tree for your civilization. See which buildings, units, and technologies you can research. A single-player game pauses when the tree is displayed, but a multiplayer game continues without you.
key_value.41104:
Lock Gate
Lock the Gate so it does not open when your units try to pass through it.
key_value.41105:
Unlock Gate
Unlock the Gate so your units can pass through it.

Drop Relic
Drop the relic this Monk is carrying. You do not control the relic if you drop it.
key_value.41107:
Deposit Resources
Take the resources to the nearest drop-off building and wait there for further instructions.
key_value.41108:
Idle Villager
Go to the next idle villager, Fishing Ship, Trade Cog, Trade Cart, or building with garrisoned units. Note: The default key to go to idle military units is the COMMA (,) key.
key_value.41110:
Turn Help Off
Disable the Help that appears in this area.
key_value.41111:
Ring Town Bell
Villagers stop working and garrison inside the Town Center for protection during attacks. Ring the bell again to send the villagers back to work.
key_value.41112:
Research Treason (Gold: 400)
Reveal the position of all enemy Kings to your team for a few seconds. The Kings appear on the mini-map as a flashing X. Each time you research Treason, 400 gold is immediately deducted from your stockpile. (Only available in Regicide game.)
key_value.41113:
Research Spies (‹cost›)
Reveal all enemy units and buildings by showing you their line of sight. The total cost is 200 gold per each enemy villager.
key_value.41114:
Research Treason (‹cost›)
Reveal the position of all enemy Kings to your team for a few seconds. The Kings appear on the mini-map as a flashing X. Each time you research Treason, 400 gold is immediately deducted from your stockpile. (Only available in Regicide game.)

key_value.42121: Click to select this %s. Hold down CTRL and click to unselect.
key_value.42122: Click to select this %s. Hold down CTRL and click to unselect. Hold down SHIFT and click to select like units.
key_value.42123: Click to subtract from the queue of farms to reseed.

key_value.42134: Click to unload this %s. Hold down CTRL and click for all other units. Hold down SHIFT and click for all like units
key_value.42135: Click to ungarrison this %s. Hold down CTRL and click for all other units. Hold down SHIFT and click for all like units.
key_value.42220:
Achievements Score
Display the individual scores of all players.
key_value.42221:
Military Stats
Display the military achievements of all players.
key_value.42222:
Economy Stats
Display the economic achievements of all players.
key_value.42223:
Technology Stats
Display the technological achievements of all players.
key_value.42224:
Society Stats
Display the societal achievements of all players.
key_value.42225:
Timeline
Display the timeline for all players.
key_value.42228: Play through the official campaigns based on real world historical events or choose from community-created campaigns.
key_value.42300: Military score is 20% of the resource value (cost) of all enemy units and buildings each player destroyed or converted.
key_value.42301: Economy score is 10% of all resources each player currently has or has paid in tribute, plus 20% of the resource value of surviving units and standing buildings (except Castles or Wonders).
key_value.42302: Technology score is 20% of the resource value of every technology each player has researched, plus 10 points for every 1% of the map explored.
key_value.42303: Society score is 20% of the cost of the Castles and Wonders each player has constructed.
key_value.42304: Total Score is the overall total of each player's Military, Economy, Technology, and Society scores.
key_value.42310: Number of enemy units each player killed with units or defenses.
key_value.42311: Number of units each player lost to enemy attacks and defenses.
key_value.42312: Number of enemy buildings each player destroyed.
key_value.42313: Number of buildings each player lost.
key_value.42314: Number of units and buildings that each player's Monks converted.
key_value.42315: Number of military units that make up each player's army.
key_value.42320: Total food collected by each player.
key_value.42321: Total wood harvested by each player.
key_value.42322: Total stone mined by each player.
key_value.42323: Total gold mined by each player.
key_value.42324: Profit from each player's combined land and sea trade.
key_value.42325: Value of commodities paid in tribute by each player to all other players.
key_value.42326: Value received in tribute from all other players.
key_value.42330: Game time in which each player advanced to the Feudal Age.
key_value.42331: Game time in which each player advanced to the Castle Age.
key_value.42332: Game time in which each player advanced to the Imperial Age.
key_value.42333: Percentage of the map explored by each player.
key_value.42334: Total number of technologies researched by each player.
key_value.42335: Percentage of technologies researched of the total possible for each player's civilization.
key_value.42340: Number of Wonders constructed by each player.
key_value.42341: Number of Castles constructed by each player.
key_value.42342: Number of relics captured by each player.
key_value.42343: Gold generated by relics stored in Monasteries by each player.
key_value.42344: The highest villager population attained by each player.
key_value.42345: Indicates whether or not the player survived until the end of the game.
key_value.42390: The player's name and color. A crown indicates a winner, and a medal the Most Valuable Player.
key_value.42391: A display of player villager (light) and military (dark) population as a percentage of the world population.
key_value.43000:
Mini-map
Shows the entire gameplay area on a smaller scale. To navigate using the mini-map, click a location, or drag the white box to view a specific area.
key_value.43020:
Selected Object
Shows which villager, building, military unit, or ship is currently selected. Villagers are shown as foragers, hunters, etc., depending on their current task.
key_value.43021:
Hit Points
Shows the current/maximum damage this unit can suffer before it is destroyed. Hit points are also indicated by a bar above the unit on the game map. Monks and garrisoning inside buildings will heal the hit points of wounded units. Villagers can repair the hit points of damaged buildings, ships, and siege weapons.
key_value.43024:
Attack Strength
Shows how much damage the unit or building can inflict.
key_value.43025:
Armor
Shows how much protection the unit or building has from normal/pierce attacks. Normal armor reduces damage from hand-to-hand combat. Pierce armor reduces damage from missile weapons (Archery Range units, siege weapons, towers, and some ships).
key_value.43026:
Range
Shows how far the unit or building can fire. Generally, ranged units cannot fire at units close to them.
key_value.43027:
Monk Faith
Shows how much faith the Monk has. Monks must renew their faith after a successful conversion. When a Monk's faith is at 100 percent, he can attempt another conversion.
key_value.43028:
Garrisoned Units
Shows the current/maximum number of units garrisoned inside this building. Buildings with garrisoned units have multiple hit point (green) lines above them on the game map. Click the Ungarrison button (on the left) to eject all units. Click the picture of the unit(s) (on the right) to eject specific units.
key_value.43029:
Food
Shows the amount of food on a Fishing Ship.
key_value.43030:
Gold on Trade Cog
Shows the amount of gold on a Trade Cog.
key_value.43032:
Food Held by Villager
Shows the amount of food the villager has.
key_value.43033:
Wood Held by Villager
Shows the amount of wood the villager has.
key_value.43034:
Gold Held by Villager
Shows the amount of gold the villager has.
key_value.43035:
Stone Held by Villager
Shows the amount of stone the villager has.
key_value.43036:
Food in This Object
Shows the amount of food this object will provide.
key_value.43037:
Wood in This Tree
Shows the amount of wood this tree will provide.
key_value.43038:
Gold in This Mine
Shows the amount of gold available in this mine.
key_value.43039:
Stone in This Mine
Shows the amount of stone available in this mine.
key_value.43040:
Gold Available by Trading Here
Shows the amount of gold available by trading here with a Trade Cog or Trade Cart.
key_value.43041:
Building Attack Strength
Shows the attack strength of this building.

key_value.43120: Hold down SHIFT and click to unselect this %s.
key_value.43121: Click to select only this %s. Hold down CTRL and click to unselect this unit.
key_value.43122: Click to select only this %s. Hold down CTRL and click to unselect this unit. Hold down SHIFT and click to select all units of this type. Hold down CTRL+SHIFT and click to unselect all units of this type.
key_value.43132: Click to unload this %s. Hold down CTRL and click to unload all other units. Hold down SHIFT and click to unload all units of this type.
key_value.43133:
Ungarrison
Click to ungarrison only this %s. Hold down CTRL and click to ungarrison all other units. Hold down SHIFT and click to ungarrison all units of this type.
key_value.43134: Click to unload only this %s. Hold down CTRL and click to unload all other units. Hold down SHIFT and click to unload all units of this type; hold down CTRL+SHIFT and click to unload all units not of this type.
key_value.43135: Click to ungarrison only this %s. Hold down CTRL and click to ungarrison all other units. Hold down SHIFT and click to ungarrison all like units of this type; hold down CTRL+SHIFT and click to ungarrison all units not of this type.
key_value.43201:
Food Stockpile
Shows how much food you have. Food is used to create new units and to advance to the next age. Villagers gather food from forage bushes, deer, sheep, turkeys, cows, llamas, goats, javelina, wild boars, elephants, ostriches, zebras, Farms, and fish. Fishing Ships also gather food from fishing and Fish Traps.
key_value.43202:
Wood Stockpile
Shows how much wood you have. Wood is used to construct buildings and ships. Villagers gather wood from trees. You can also buy wood at the Market or receive a tribute of wood from other players.
key_value.43203:
Gold Stockpile
Shows how much gold you have. Gold is used to create some units and research some technologies. Villagers gather gold from gold mines. You can also increase your gold by trading with other players; selling stone, wood, or food; or garrisoning a relic in a Monastery.
key_value.43204:
Stone Stockpile
Shows how much stone you have. Stone is used to build walls, towers, and some buildings. Villagers gather stone from stone mines. You can also buy stone at the Market or receive a tribute of stone from other players.
key_value.43205:
Population Indicator
Shows your current/supportable population. Before you can create new villagers, military units, or ships, you must have enough Houses to support them. The population indicator flashes if you need to build more houses before creating or building new units.
key_value.44002: But if we're to defeat them, every one of us will need to learn how to march and fight.
key_value.44003: Follow the path to the blue flag. First, click the soldier …
key_value.44004: Good. Now RIGHT-click near the blue flag.
key_value.44005: Good! Now move to the next flag. Click the soldier, then RIGHT-click near the flag.
key_value.44006: Moving into the black area reveals more of the map. The black area represents unexplored territory.
key_value.44007: Excellent. To move to the next flag, you must walk through the black area.
key_value.44008: RIGHT-click the Outpost to attack it.
key_value.44009: Follow the instructions to reach the Scottish village.
key_value.44010: Good job! Now you know how to fight back against the English army!
key_value.44011: The English are terrorizing all of Scotland, and it's time for us to fight back!
key_value.44012: That's all there is to it. Now go on to the next flag, where you will meet some allied soldiers.
key_value.44013: Did all of your units make it to the flag?
key_value.44014: The Outpost is destroyed! That should slow the English raids.
key_value.44015: To move all of your soldiers at once, click near the units and drag around them. Then RIGHT-click to move them. Try moving your soldiers to the next flag.
key_value.44016: Keep following the path to the village.
key_value.44018: But wait! The English are angry that you destroyed their Outpost! They are coming to attack your village!
key_value.44019:
Don't panic. Just click your soldiers and RIGHT-click the red English soldiers to attack.
Defeat the enemy soldiers, and you will have won your first battle.
key_value.44020: Good. Now scroll back down until you can see your soldiers again by moving your mouse to the very bottom of the screen. Select your soldiers by clicking near them and dragging a box around them.
key_value.44021: The road ahead is guarded by an English Outpost. Scroll up to the Outpost building by moving the mouse to the very top of the screen. Then click the red Outpost.
key_value.44022: Keep following the road to the Outpost. It's time to knock it down!
key_value.44101: The villager will continue working for you, carrying the food to the Town Center.
key_value.44102: The amount of food you have is shown in the upper-left corner of the screen. In addition to your food stockpile, you can see your current wood, gold, and stone stockpiles.
key_value.44103: The more villagers you have, the faster you can gather resources. Assign your new villagers to gather food.
key_value.44104: To gather wood, click a villager, then RIGHT-click a tree.
key_value.44105: Great! You now have 50 food. To win, also gather 50 wood and 50 gold.
key_value.44107: You are well on your way to making a city!
key_value.44108: To gather food from the forage bush, click a villager …
key_value.44111: If you haven't found any gold yet, search in the unexplored territory.
key_value.44112: To support the Scottish army, you will need to build up your stockpile of resources.
key_value.44113: … then RIGHT-click a forage bush near the blue flag.
key_value.44114: To win, gather 50 food, 50 wood, and 50 gold.
key_value.44115: Excellent! You now have enough gold.
key_value.44116: Good job! You now have enough wood.
key_value.44117: In the status area at the bottom of the screen, you can see how much food the villager is carrying. The villager continues to gather from the forage bush until he is carrying 10 food.
key_value.44201: We'll start by creating villagers. Click your Town Center …
key_value.44202: … then click the Create Villager button in the lower-left corner of the screen.
key_value.44203: It takes time for a villager to appear. If your Town Center is selected, you can see the progress in the status area at the bottom of your screen.
key_value.44204: Good job. The villager has appeared next to your Town Center. Now, create another villager.
key_value.44205: You need additional housing to support your population. To build a House, click a villager.
key_value.44206: Other buildings are made just like Houses. Try building a Barracks. The Barracks is a military building.
key_value.44207: If more than one villager builds a building, it will go up faster.
key_value.44209: Now that you have a few soldiers, you will be able to defend this area against English attacks.
key_value.44210: That's one Militia unit. Create three more and you will have enough soldiers to protect this area and win the scenario.
key_value.44211: Good job! Try building another House.
key_value.44212: Barracks complete! Now you can create soldiers. Click the Barracks, then click the Create Militia button.
key_value.44213: Click the Barracks, and quickly click the Create Militia button three more times to make three soldiers in a row.
key_value.44214: Click the Buildings button, click the Build House button, then click where you want to build the House.
key_value.44215: Each House supports 5 units. The population indicator at the top of the screen shows your current/supportable population.
key_value.44216:
We will need many soldiers to defend our homeland.
To win, you will need to create 4 Militia.
key_value.44217: Selecting different buildings or units gives you different options in the lower-left corner of the screen.
key_value.44302: You are going to need to research some technologies of your own to increase the strength of your civilization.
key_value.44303: For example, researching Loom makes your villagers harder to kill. To research Loom, click the Town Center, then click the Research Loom button.
key_value.44304: New technologies and buildings become available when you advance to a new age. To advance from the Dark Age to the Feudal Age, you need 500 food.
key_value.44305: In addition to gathering food at forage bushes, villagers can herd sheep or hunt deer for food.
key_value.44306: Now you have enough food to advance to the Feudal Age. However, you also need two buildings from your current age.
key_value.44307: You already have a Barracks, so now have your villagers build a Mill. The Mill is a drop-off point for food, so build it next to your food source.
key_value.44308: Now you can advance from the Dark Age to the Feudal Age. Click your Town Center, then click the Advance to Feudal Age button.
key_value.44309: To arms! The English are making a sneak attack!
key_value.44310: Now that the battle is over, create some extra Militia units at the Barracks to replenish your forces.
key_value.44311: Now that you are in the Feudal Age, you can upgrade your Militia to Men-at-Arms. Click the Barracks, then click Upgrade to Man-at-Arms.
key_value.44312: The English are attacking again! Teach them a lesson with your new Men-at-Arms!
key_value.44313: The English are no match for your warriors!
key_value.44314: Good. Researching technology costs resources but improves your civilization.
key_value.44315: While researching, you can put your villagers to work and use your military units to explore.
key_value.44316: Congratulations! Advancing to the next age is the best way to improve your civilization.
key_value.44317: Good. You are on your way to the Feudal Age.
key_value.44318: To win, you will need to advance to the Feudal Age and repel the English raids.
key_value.44319: The English use very advanced weapons and armor.
key_value.44320: Upgrading to Man-at-Arms will change all your Militia units to the more powerful Men-at-Arms.
key_value.44321: Near the mini-map in the lower-right corner of the screen is the Idle Villager button. Click it, and locate villagers who are not currently assigned to a task.
key_value.44402: Objective: Build an army and defeat the English fort.
key_value.44403:
This scenario begins in a similar way to Random Map games. After you play this scenario, you should know all you need to play a Random Map game.

Keep exploring!
key_value.44404: The time has come to take the offensive. The English have a fort near the town of Stirling. If we can defeat the English here, they may think twice about their invasion of Scotland.
key_value.44405: Before we attack the English to the west, we need to build up our forces. Have your villagers start gathering food and wood.
key_value.44406: Keep making villagers at your Town Center until you have 10. The more villagers you have, the faster your resources will come in.
key_value.44407: You can gain more food by building Fishing Ships. To create Fishing Ships, have your villagers build a Dock in the water to the south.
key_value.44408: Now click the Dock, and build a Fishing Ship.
key_value.44409: To fish, click a Fishing Ship and RIGHT-click on a leaping fish. The Fishing Ship will collect fish and automatically return them to the Dock. Fishing Ships are also useful for exploring.
key_value.44410: Scout Cavalry are poor fighters but they can see a great distance. You can use your Scout Cavalry to explore the rest of the map and find the English.
key_value.44411: The hill with the dead tree protects the only access to your town. It would be a good idea to build a Watch Tower on this hill once you advance to the Feudal Age.
key_value.44412: An English Outpost! You know what to do … knock it down!
key_value.44413: You are close to the English base. Better not knock down this wall until you have an army of about 12 soldiers.
key_value.44414: Now you have a large enough force to attack the English base. Charge! Keep your villagers working just in case you suffer casualties and need to make more troops.
key_value.44415: Defeat the English army and destroy their Tower.
key_value.44416: Great job! You have destroyed the English camp. The Battle of Stirling is sure to end in victory for the Scots!
key_value.44417: Now that you have reached the Feudal Age, concentrate on making some soldiers to fight the enemy. You will need at least 12.
key_value.44418: The English are coming to attack! To protect your villagers, you can use the town bell to garrison them in your Town Center. Click your Town Center, then click Town Bell.
key_value.44419: Good! You defeated the English assault. If you have villagers in your Town Center, ring the town bell again to send them back to work.
key_value.44420: Good! Your Watch Tower will fire on enemy units and help protect your town.
key_value.44421: You have found some sheep! Sheep are a good source of food, so send them back to your Town Center and assign a villager to gather food from them.
key_value.44422: Now that you know how to build up, advance through the ages, and find and fight your enemies, you have all the basic skills you need to play a Random Map game, the most common type of game in Age of Empires II.
key_value.44423: Remember, you can upgrade your Militia to Men-at-Arms at the Barracks. You should always upgrade soldiers when you can afford it.
key_value.44424: Build a Barracks and 5 Militia to defend your villagers and explore the map.
key_value.44425: To win, destroy the English tower to the west.
key_value.44426: Use your villagers to build a Mill near your forage bushes.
key_value.44427: Once you have gathered 500 food, advance to the Feudal Age at your Town Center. If you are low on food, build some additional Farms.
key_value.44428: Remember to upgrade weapons and armor at the Blacksmith. You do have a Blacksmith, don't you?
key_value.44429: Villagers can also build Farms. Build 4 Farms near your Mill when your forage bushes are depleted. Each Farm needs only one villager working on it.
key_value.44430: Good job! You have eliminated the English soldiers. Now destroy that tower and our victory will be complete.
key_value.44431: You can specify a location for new units to gather by setting a gather point. For villagers, click the Town Center and click the Set Gather Point button.
key_value.44432: Don't forget, keep exploring the map.
key_value.44503: Use your Monks to collect 3 relics and garrison them in your Monastery.
key_value.44504:
This scenario uses the advanced commands interface. Although you do not need to use this interface to play Age of Empires II: HD Edition, it does provide access to some more powerful ways to control your civilization.

If you lose your monks, you can make more when you get to the Castle Age.
key_value.44505: The Scottish army has been rallied by recent victories against the English. The situation is starting to look up.
key_value.44506: It will help the morale of our army to collect holy relics and place them in our Monastery. One of the relics is close to your town. An ally has another relic, and the English have captured a third.
key_value.44507: You can retrieve a relic by clicking a Monk and RIGHT-clicking the relic. Monks have other abilities as well. They can heal your injured soldiers or those of your allies. They can also attempt to convert enemy soldiers to join your army.
key_value.44508: Good, you have a relic! Protect the relic in the Monastery by RIGHT-clicking the Monastery.
key_value.44509: It is nice to have allies on the map. Your ally (the yellow player) can help you fight the enemy. You can also trade with your allies. To trade, you will need to build a Market.
key_value.44510: You have a Market! The Market can create Trade Carts to generate extra gold. You can also exchange one resource for another at the Market for a small fee. Click the Market, then click Sell Food for Gold.
key_value.44511: You made a Trade Cart! If you click the Trade Cart on your ally's Market, you can make extra gold. Your Trade Cart will automatically make trips between your and your ally's Markets.
key_value.44512: Scottish ally: Welcome! If you have come for the relic, you can find it on the hill to the northeast of our town.
key_value.44513: Scottish ally: The English are attacking our town! Can you tribute any spare food or gold to us?
key_value.44514: To tribute your ally, click the Diplomacy button in the upper-right corner of the screen. Give your ally some food and gold, but don't give him everything you own!
key_value.44515: Scottish ally: Thanks for the resources. If you have any spare soldiers, come to our town and let's drive the English out!
key_value.44516: You have enough soldiers now to think about attacking the English and recovering their relic.
key_value.44517: Scottish ally: If you are getting ready to attack the English, I can help you out. Here, take this food and wood.
key_value.44518: Capture 3 relics and garrison them in your Monastery.
key_value.44519: Congratulations! You have captured all 3 relics!
key_value.44520: You have reached your ally's town. Go inside to see how his city is doing. Your ally's gate will open automatically for you.
key_value.44521: Farms are a good source of food once you have exhausted forage bushes and animals. Farms are built like buildings and must be periodically rebuilt. To gather food from a Farm, click a villager, then RIGHT-click a Farm.
key_value.44522: Villagers and soldiers normally appear outside of the building that created them. You can have your units move to a spot once they are created by using gather points.
key_value.44523: To set a gather point for infantry, click your Barracks, click Set Gather Point, then click where on the map you want your infantry to gather.
key_value.44524: You can use the technology tree to see what technologies and upgrades you can research. Click the Technology Tree button in the upper-right corner of the screen to see the tree for your civilization.
key_value.44525: Did you know that there are three different modes for the mini-map in the lower-right corner of the screen? You can show only military units, or only resources and trade units, by clicking the buttons just below and to the right of the mini-map.
key_value.44526: Perfect, you now have 1 relic garrisoned. Relics garrisoned in your Monastery will slowly add gold to your stockpile.
key_value.44527: You now have 2 relics garrisoned. Bring back one more and you will be victorious!
key_value.44603:
This scenario uses the advanced commands interface. Although you do not need to use this interface to play Age of Empires II: HD Edition, it does provide access to some more powerful ways to control your civilization.

Different civilizations have different strengths. For example the Scots, who are represented by the Celtic civilization, have powerful infantry. The Britons have long-range archers.
key_value.44605: The English castle at Falkirk is no more! The English pretensions in Scotland are surely at an end. The forces of Wallace are triumphant.
key_value.44607: Great! You have completed the Castle. Sir William should be here soon, and then it will be time to attack the English!
key_value.44609: The English could attack at any time. You have some walls already, but you should complete them as soon as you have enough stone.
key_value.44610: One of your most powerful units is created at the Castle. Create 10 more Woad Raiders.
key_value.44611: Trebuchets are massive siege weapons with a great range, available only in the Imperial Age. Remember that Trebuchets must be packed to move and unpacked to fire.
key_value.44612: To build a Castle, you must first advance to the next age: the Castle Age.
key_value.44613: You also can build towers to defend your city. Units can garrison within a tower for defense and protection and archers can even fire out of a tower.
key_value.44614: Congratulations. You are going to find lots of things to do in the Castle Age. For starters, try building a Siege Workshop to make Battering Rams and other siege weapons.
key_value.44615: Good job. With your new Siege Workshop you can make Battering Rams. Rams are slow, but they are resistant to arrow fire and excellent at knocking down walls. You may need some rams to attack the English castle.
key_value.44616: You may need to assign extra villagers to gather stone so you'll have enough to build the Castle and all of the fortifications you need.
key_value.44617: The advanced buttons allow access to a new type of formation. For example, with a box formation, you can protect a weak unit.
key_value.44618: The advanced buttons let you set combat states for your soldiers. A defensive soldier will be less likely to attack an enemy that comes near him. Click a military unit, then note the combat stance buttons in the lower-left corner of the screen.
key_value.44619: Using the advanced buttons, you can also command a soldier to patrol an area between two points and guard or follow another unit.
key_value.44620: With William Wallace and his Woad Raiders on your side, the English may be in trouble. Once you have a large army with plenty of siege weapons, go destroy the English Castle!
key_value.44621: If you have surplus resources of one type, you can sell them for gold at your Market. You can then use the gold to buy what you need.
key_value.44622: You have enough resources to go to the Castle Age—you should do that soon.
key_value.44706:
Escort Joan from the camp at Vaucouleurs to the Château of Chinon.

Joan must survive.
key_value.44707:
France's enemies are Britain and Burgundy. Be on the lookout for their forces.

Do not expect much assistance from the demoralized Army of France, but be alert for any soldiers who might be inspired to join your army … once they see Joan.

Protect your two Knights. They are your best fighters and know the lay of the land.

Don't worry about your economy—just get Joan to her destination.

Keep an eye on Joan's health: If it gets too low, keep her away from dangerous situations.
key_value.44708: Scout: I spotted a nest of Burgundians to the north. Best to go another way.
key_value.44709: De Metz: The bridge is out. The British must have destroyed it. We must find another way to Chinon.
key_value.44710: De Metz: A Burgundian encampment! We'll never get through that wall without siege equipment.
key_value.44711: Swordsman: Gather your belongings men—we follow Joan of Arc! We will carry that Battering Ram along with us. It may yet be of use.
key_value.44712: De Metz: An ambuscade! There are Burgundian soldiers everywhere! Hurry west to the river, where we can made our escape!
key_value.44713: Bertrand: Chinon! We have made it.
key_value.44714: French soldier: The château of the Dauphin!
key_value.44715:
Escort Joan from the camp at Vaucouleurs to the Château of Chinon.

Joan must survive.
key_value.44716: Courtier: The Dauphin will see you now.
key_value.44717: Bertrand: We need a Mangonel or ram to get through these walls.
key_value.44718: Swordsman: Are you mad? Across that bridge lies a Burgundian castle and many men! Turn back at once!
key_value.44720: French soldier: Mon dieu! We have lost Bertrand!
key_value.44721: French soldier: De Metz has given his life for the cause!
key_value.44722: French soldier: Joan has fallen! A black day!
key_value.44723: De Metz: Another glorious loss for France. I hope you really can turn the tide of this war, Joan of Arc.
key_value.44724: Spearman: You must be wary on the road ahead. Our enemies, the British, are out in force and their Burgundian allies are thick as rats. Discretion is the better part of valor.
key_value.44725: De Metz: Look out! A battle rages ahead! Stay back lest we be caught in the crossfire!
key_value.44726: Bertrand: Bonjour, Joan. My colleague and I will escort you to the château of the Dauphin, or else we will die trying.
key_value.44727: Swordsman: You are Joan of Arc … I have heard your claims and believe what you say. We will follow you to Chinon!
key_value.44728: Crossbowman: Wait! You might have need of a few archers on the road ahead.
key_value.44729: Burgundian soldier: You French don't know when to give up!
key_value.44730: Bertrand: Highwaymen preying on helpless travelers. What has become of our homeland?
key_value.44731: Crossbowman: You mean to lead the French army? Such confidence I have not seen since this war began. Very well. You have six more soldiers, Joan the Maid.
key_value.44732: Burgundian soldier: Here they come! Fire!
key_value.44733: De Metz: I am Jean de Metz, and I will protect you with my life.
key_value.44807:
Escort Joan to Blois so she may lead the French army.

Deliver the 6 carts of supplies to the Orléans Town Center.

Convince the British armies to withdraw by destroying one of their Castles.

Prevent the Orléans Cathedral from being destroyed. Joan must survive.
key_value.44808:
Hurry to Orléans before the English can cause much damage. Be wary of British forces south of the river, but don't forget to rendezvous with your army in Blois.

Once the supplies arrive in Orléans, you will be able to build up your forces. Frankish Knights are useful for taking care of British longbows and siege weapons. Frankish Castles are inexpensive and provide excellent defense.

Use your Market to trade for resources until you can venture outside the city.

The British Castles have large garrisons. It is best to assemble a large attack force before attempting to storm them.

Orléans farms are located west of the city, but outside of the city walls and vulnerable.
key_value.44809: Deliver 6 Trade Carts of supplies to the Orléans Town Center.
key_value.44810: Orléans villager: Hurrah! Joan of Arc has brought us supplies! Now we can muster the forces we need to raze one of the British Castles.
key_value.44811: Alençon: This Burgundian rabble shall not stop us!
key_value.44812: Get Joan to the Orléans Town Center.
key_value.44813: Orléans villager: Joan the Maid has come! We are saved!
key_value.44814: French soldier: Now, on to Orléans! We need to get those supplies past the British.
key_value.44815: Alençon: I am the Duke D'Alençon, my lady. I will proudly ride with you to Orléans.
key_value.44816: French soldier: The cathedral has been destroyed!
key_value.44818: French soldier: The Duke D'Alençon has fallen in battle!
key_value.44819: French soldier: Lament, for we have lost Joan!
key_value.44820: French soldier: We have failed in our mission! Orléans will not get the supplies it needs.
key_value.44821: Convince the British to withdraw by destroying 1 of their Castles.
key_value.44822: North British: Since we are a generous people, we will allow you to stay in Orléans. But France belongs to Britain now; never forget that!
key_value.44823: South British: Can it be that the French have finally learned to fight?
key_value.44824: Orléans villager: Our city needs help! The British are coming!
key_value.44825: Orléans villager: The British are destroying our towers! You must save Orléans!
key_value.44826: Escort Joan to Blois so she may command the French army.
key_value.44827: French soldier: Welcome to Blois, Joan of Arc. The army of France is yours to command!
key_value.44828:
Joan must survive.

The cathedral in Orléans must remain standing.
key_value.44904:
Destroy at least 3 British Castles.

Joan must survive.
key_value.44905:
Make sure you have ample siege weapons before assaulting the English Castles.

The area across the river and to the east should have plenty of resources to begin your town.
key_value.44906: French soldier: With these ships, we can cross the Loire River and deal with any British warships we encounter.
key_value.44907: Fastolf: Enough of this! I shall deal with Joan of Arc.
key_value.44908: French soldier: With two British Castles destroyed, we have but one more to raze!.
key_value.44909:
Destroy at least 3 British Castles.

Joan must survive.
key_value.44910: French soldier: That's the last of them. The British will be forced to surrender the Loire Valley back to the French. Another victory for Joan of Arc!
key_value.44911: French soldier: La Hire has been grievously wounded!
key_value.44912: French soldier: We have lost Joan! What shall become of France now?
key_value.44913: Fastolf: I come for you, Joan of Arc!
key_value.44914: La Hire: The blood on La Hire's sword is almost dry.
key_value.44915: La Hire: Them Brits can't make a castle stronger than La Hire!
key_value.44916: La Hire: Do your worst, you English fop!
key_value.44918: British: The French are attacking our castles!
key_value.44919: La Hire: La Hire wishes to kill something.
key_value.44920: Fastolf: Methinks this peasant girl should go back to her sheep.
key_value.44921: Fastolf: We'll see how your knights fare against British longbows!
key_value.44922: Fastolf: An army of rams. How quaint.
key_value.45005:
Travel west to help reinforce the French town. Be wary of opposition along the way.

Joan must survive.
key_value.45006:
Gaining control of the river may be a good strategy, but do not squander your resources needlessly on ships.

Chalon is the closest and most vulnerable of the three English-occupied villages. Making an example of them early could help even the odds for you in the long run.

Remember your objectives. It is not necessary to level the cities, only to force the English to withdraw.

Wall off all shallows to slow enemy invaders.
key_value.45007: Destroy the Town Center of Troyes.
key_value.45008: French soldier: The British in Troyes have been defeated!
key_value.45009: Destroy the Town Center of Chalons.
key_value.45010: French soldier: Chalons has been freed!
key_value.45011: Destroy the Town Center of Rheims.
key_value.45012: French soldier: Rheims has been liberated!
key_value.45014: French soldier: We will bury Joan beside the river.
key_value.45015: Rheims: To arms! The French are trying to cross the river!
key_value.45016: Rheims: To arms! The French are trying to cross the river!
key_value.45017: British guards: Joan of Arc is attacking our camp!
key_value.45018: Rheims: Do not let her cross the river!
key_value.45019: French villager: We were assigned to help you construct your military camp.
key_value.45020: French soldier: Now the coronation of the Dauphin can proceed!
key_value.45021: Rheims: To arms! The French are trying to cross the river!
key_value.45022: Travel west to help reinforce the French town. Be wary of opposition along the way.
key_value.45105: Refugee villagers in Paris are attempting to escape English tyranny. Locate at least 6 of the refugees.
key_value.45106:
Don't try and defeat every British unit. Focus on your objectives.

Guard your siege weapons. Towers will be a big problem if you don't.

If faced with overwhelming opposition, run away! Run away!
key_value.45107: Militia: We are tired of licking British boots. We follow where you lead, Joan of Arc!
key_value.45108: Rendezvous with the king's reinforcements in Paris, just south of the river bridge.
key_value.45109: French soldier: We should wait here. The king's reinforcements will be along any second.
key_value.45110: French soldier: Where are those blasted reinforcements?
key_value.45111: French soldier: Treachery! The king's wicked advisors want to see Joan defamed … or worse! We're on our own! We must hurry to Compiègne!
key_value.45112: French soldier: We have rescued the refugees! Now we should head to the bridge at the Seine River for the rendezvous with the king's men.
key_value.45113: Burgundy: There she is! This time she won't escape!
key_value.45114: French soldier: My lady, this is the wrong way! We must get to the Château of Compiègne!
key_value.45115: Escort Joan and at least 6 of the refugees to the Château of Compiègne (the square between the flags).
key_value.45116: Compiègne: You are victorious and our peasants are safe! I just hope Joan can make it to the Castle.
key_value.45118: French soldier: Joan has fallen in battle! If only the king had helped us! Alas!
key_value.45119: Scout: We are all the king could afford to send.
key_value.45120: Paladin: Paris is just ahead. Let us locate the refugees and escort them to the rendezvous point with the king's men.
key_value.45204:
Rendezvous with the French army, commanded by Constable Richemont./n/nRendezvous with the French artillery, commanded by Jean Bureau.

Plant the French flag (loaded in a Trade Cart) on the hill in Castillon (covered with flags).
key_value.45205:
Most of the land here is occupied. You will have to displace Burgundy in order to build a town. Don't knock down all of Burgundy's walls—you can use them for your own defense.

Longbowmen are powerful, but Bombard Cannons are better!

You can order Bombard Cannons and other siege weapons to the No Attack Stance if they are hurting your own troops.
key_value.45206: French soldier: Lord Josselyne, the army awaits your command.
key_value.45207: Rendezvous with the French army, commanded by Constable Richemont.
key_value.45208: Richemont: We fight for the maid of Orléans!
key_value.45209: Rendezvous with the French artillery, commanded by Jean Bureau.
key_value.45210: Jean Bureau: We'll see how British longbows fare against French cannon!
key_value.45211: French soldier: M'lord, we have captured the Burgundian's stockpile of resources.
